description: From Middle English ravine, from Old French raviner (“rush, seize by force”), itself from ravine (“rapine”), from Latin rapīna (“plundering, loot”), itself from rapere (“seize, plunder, abduct”).

adjectives.description: ravin (comparative more ravin, superlative most ravin)

entries.meaning: (obsolete) Food obtained by violence; plunder; prey; raven.

verbs.description: ravin (third-person singular simple present ravins, present participle ravining, simple past and past participle ravined)

entries.meaning: (obsolete) To dine or feast upon plunder or goods seized by violence.
examples: Now, if ye hear the bruit of death or wounds,Give not yourselves o'ermuch to shriek and scream,For Ares ravins upon human flesh.
